title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.13.30 | 12-10-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: Om Agyanati Mirandhasya Gyananjanishalakaya Chaksharanmeelitham Yena Tasmai Shri Gurave Namaha
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and mantras, invoking blessings and paying respects to the spiritual master.

segments.key_quote: The gentle and chaste Gandhari, who was the daughter of King Subala of Kandahar or Gandhara, followed her husband, seeing that he was going to the Himalaya mountains, which are the delightful mountains, which are the delight of those who have accepted the staff of the renounced order, like fighters who have accepted a good lashing from the enemy.
segments.summary: Suta Goswami describes Gandhari's decision to follow her husband Dhritarashtra to the Himalayas, highlighting her chastity and devotion.

segments.key_quote: The Vedic civilization especially prepares chaste and devoted wives, of whom Gandhari is one amongst many mentioned in history.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on Gandhari's qualities as a Sadhvi and Pativrata, emphasizing the importance of chaste and devoted wives in Vedic culture.

segments.key_quote: Just like Sita voluntarily chose to follow her husband and go to the forest with him, similarly Gandhari, she voluntarily accepted to follow her husband and go with him to the Himalayas.
segments.summary: The speaker draws a parallel between Gandhari and Sita, highlighting their voluntary sacrifices and devotion to their husbands, despite the hardships involved.

segments.key_quote: As a chaste lady, Gandhari decided to follow her husband till the last moment.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that Gandhari's decision to follow Dhritarashtra was voluntary and emphasizes Dhritarashtra's detachment and Gandhari's unwavering devotion.

segments.key_quote: These are all based on a very advanced culture and civilization in the Vedic culture.
segments.summary: The speaker explains the stages of Varna Ashrama, focusing on Vanaprastha and Sanyas, and the rules regarding a wife's association with her husband in each stage, highlighting the advanced nature of Vedic culture.

segments.key_quote: Sanyas is only for those who want to dedicate themselves for traveling and preaching without any other responsibility. Otherwise, Sanyas in Kali Yuga is forbidden.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses the prohibition of Sanyas in Kali Yuga, except for those who dedicate themselves to traveling and preaching, and reiterates Dhritarashtra's detachment and Gandhari's voluntary following.

segments.key_quote: The Vaishnava Sanyasis from the beginning they learn to depend on Krishna. The Supreme Personality of God.
segments.summary: The speaker explains the significance of the Sanyas Danda, differentiating between Ekadanda (Mayavadi) and Tridanda (Vaishnava) Sanyasis, and their respective approaches to renunciation and dependence on Krishna, concluding with advice for Dhritarashtra.
